settings.text: Considered by those in the know as the queen of diamonds, Jessica McCormack is the New Zealand-born Mayfair designer who believes that even the finest of jewels should be worn – and enjoyed – every day. We applaud her effortless, high-low approach to dressing and her knack for accessorising love-worn denim and laidback knits with the most precious of treasures. Find out more below…

settings.grid-content:
How would you describe your style?


Jeans, tees and jumpers, and some diamonds.

With most of us spending a lot more time at home, have you adapted how you dress in the last year?


I think most of us have become more relaxed. I’ve definitely spent more time in sweats whilst at home – I’m obsessed with my Chinti & Parker cashmere ones. And I’ve probably worn less makeup in the past twelve months than ever before. Home-schooling doesn’t call for it.


Does your look change much from week to weekend?


No! When I’m in the office, I’m usually in jeans, in the summer with a vest, in the winter with a knit. So there is not much change at the weekend.

Which three pieces from your wardrobe do you rely on most?


My jeans, a navy cashmere Chinti & Parker slouchy sweater, and a pair of open toe Chanel flat sandals. Is it warm enough for them yet?

What are your go-to pieces of jewellery for every day? And do you believe in saving certain pieces for special occasions?


I’m not about saving jewellery for special occasions! If you love it, you should wear it. I always have on a pair of Gypsets – they rarely leave my ears actually; I sleep in them.

Which Chinti & Parker pieces would you style your jewels with?


I have a cool oatmeal Chinti & Parker cashmere sweater, that I’ve been pairing with some pearl Gypsets and my rose gold Ball n Chain necklaces, the rose and oatmeal go perfectly together. It feels paired back but still elegant.

What are you looking forward to wearing this spring?


I can’t wait to wear dresses again! To be able to just throw on one piece of clothing, a pair of flats, some jewellery, and still feel put together - I love that.

settings.title: How does Autumn make you feel? Best memories?
settings.text: Autumn is definitely about getting cosy.  I love nothing more than hunkering down with a fire, red wine and a box set with Charlie.  Long crispy, sunny walks and long pub lunches.  One of my favourite memories was going to London with my brothers and parents when we were small and buying roasted chestnuts on the street. I must have been about 10 and thought I’d died and gone to heaven. That delicious, hot, smoky scent, the crinkly paper bag and being out way past my bedtime. I’ve never forgotten it.
